pageContext.claim: “Many of these people [in the detention centers] were criminals. We're not letting them out. We can't let them out. And it was crowded; very crowded. And the best way they can solve that is don't come up. If you don't come up, you're not going to be crowded.”
pageContext.analysis: This is false. The Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC) at Syracuse University obtained case-by-case records on each of these 44,435 individuals held in ICE custody on June 30, 2019. "The vast majority (58 percent) of individuals in ICE custody June 30 had no criminal record," TRAC said. "An even larger proportion—four out of five—either had no record, or had only committed a minor offense such as a traffic violation. This left just one out of five who had been convicted of what ICE classified as a felony. Of these only 16 percent were what ICE defines as a serious, or Level 1, offense. Even among Level 1 offenses ICE included crimes such as 'selling marijuana' which many states have now legalized."
